title: Cat. 53  Te atua (The God), 1893/94

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Upon his return to France in late August 1893, Gauguin began to prepare an exhibition of painted and sculpted works he had created during his two years in Tahiti. In November forty-one paintings and assorted wood sculptures on Tahitian themes, along with three Brittany-related paintings, were exhibited in Paris at Galeries Durand-Ruel. Only three paintings sold.

When the exhibition closed, the unsold works returned to Gauguin. As photographs of his Paris studio at 6, rue Vercingétorix (see fig. 53.1, fig. 53.2, and fig. 53.3), and eyewitness accounts confirm, Gauguin had painted the walls a bright chrome yellow. The studio also housed paintings and woodcarvings from Gauguin’s Tahitian sojourn that were not exhibited at Durand-Ruel. Thus, by simply looking around his studio, the artist could select motifs from the array of works he had accumulated. Displayed on the yellow walls, as well as stacked on the floor, they formed a brilliantly colored environment that documented, as well as romanticized, Gauguin’s encounter with the South Seas, where he—always the outsider—felt, at least some of the time, that he had found a home. Serving as visual aids, the works allowed him to muse upon his adventures as he spun them for fellow artists and literati, made new and experimental work, and wrote and rewrote his travel account and created the accompanying prints using boxwood matrices.

The Noa Noa Suite received two printings during Gauguin’s lifetime—one in 1893–94 by the artist himself and the other in c. 1894 by his friend Louis Roy—and one key printing after his death. In 1921 Gauguin’s son Pola supervised the publication of a portfolio of black-and-white impressions pulled from eight of the ten surviving boxwood matrices for the suite. Unlike the experimental, expressive, and often hard-to-read impressions made by Gauguin and the limited but often brighter palette of those printed by Roy, Pola Gauguin’s meticulously inked and pulled prints record in a straightforward manner every detail and represent the prints’ final state. However, Pola Gauguin was unable to pull an impression of Te atua (The God) because his father had recycled the image’s boxwood matrix, using the reverse to execute two other prints. Thus the following description of the print’s components is based on impressions the artist made (cats. 53.1–4). Gauguin’s intentions for sequencing the plates in his proposed publication were never clear, which has prompted many theories. For the order of plates presented here, see “Veiled in a Cloud of Fragrance.”

Te atua, the third print in the Noa Noa Suite, moves the viewer from the realm of mortals to that of the gods who created them and determined their fate. The wood-block print features Polynesian deities who appear in much the same way in woodcarvings Gauguin made in Tahiti as early as 1892 (figs. 53.9, 53.12, 53.17, and 53.29). So close to one another are the images in Te atua and the carvings that the former seems to be a flattened version of the latter, as if the artist had produced the print by combining “rubbings” he made of the sculptures. If one joins the print’s left and right sides to form a cylinder, one can see clearly its relationship to the artist’s carvings (see fig. 53.4). The print’s components would continue to figure in Gauguin’s work in a variety of mediums and contexts throughout the remainder of his career.

The deities portrayed at the left are Hina (spirit of the moon) and Tefatu (spirit of the earth). Clad in pareus (wrap-around skirts), they are engaged in an intense dialogue about the eternity of matter. At the image’s center, the hieratic figure of Ta’aroa (creator god of the Polynesian universe and supreme deity), sits, Buddha-like, in meditation. His right hand rests in his lap, and his left touches the earth, a mudra signaling the moment of the Buddha’s enlightenment. Because of the printing process, this iconic pose reverses the traditional one, which permeates Buddhist art. At the right is another representation of Hina, accompanied by Ta’aroa, who is reduced here to a tiny, gnome-like figure crouching on bent knee below the arrowhead-shaped leaf of an ape plant (see fig. 53.5). In some versions of the Polynesian creation myth, Hina is the spouse of Ta’aroa, and Tefatu is their child. The plate’s title, “Te Atua,” appears in the top center; Gauguin’s monogram, PGo, is set within a lunette shape at the lower left.

The striated patterns that swirl over the deities suggest a meteor shower, much like the agitated sky in The Starry Night (fig. 53.6) by Vincent van Gogh, Gauguin’s host and studio companion in Arles, in the south of France, for two months in late 1888. But these forms most likely represent the blossoms, leaves, and stems of the peacock flower (see Scented Sites, fig. 9, and cat. 56), which Gauguin depicted in his 1892/93 manuscript Ancien culte mahorie (Ancient Maori Religion) (fig. 53.7).

The shrubs between the deities, as well as the rodent-like animal in front of the central figure of Ta’aroa, were inspired by similar images in the two albumen prints of Borobudur by Isidore van Kinsbergen that Gauguin owned and took with him to Tahiti (see fig. 53.8).

Silhouetted dramatically against the moon, the figures of Hina and Tefatu are based on a linga-like, tamanu wood sculpture, Hina and Fatu (Hina and Tefatu), which Gauguin executed in 1892 (fig. 53.9). References to these two deities, to whom the artist was clearly drawn, abound in his graphic work.

Among the many images of Hina and Tefatu that relate directly to Te atua is one—Parau Hina Tefatou (Hina Addressing Tefatu)—that Gauguin selected as the frontispiece of the catalogue for his Durand-Ruel exhibition (fig. 53.10). The now-lost pen-and-ink drawing used for the photomechanical reproduction relates directly to the above-mentioned tamanu sculpture, including the tattoos on Hina’s face.

A sheet featuring several sketches (fig. 53.11 left) includes one of Hina, after a tamanu sculpture, Hina with Two Attendants (fig. 53.12). As in the sculpture, Hina bends her elbows to raise her forearms; in the print, her arms hang alongside her body. The sketch of Hina and Tefatu, which is squared off, was an idea for a painting or an illustration. Tefatu, who wears a pareu, and Hina, who is naked, crouch along a shore: Gauguin’s hallmark patterned water can be seen in the foreground. Behind Tefatu one discerns the faint outline of a tupapau (a spirit of the dead) and indications of a landscape setting. The sketch is closely linked to both the sculpture Hina and Fatu and Te atua, as can be seen if one reverses the drawing (fig. 53.11 right). However, several variations and the details included in the foreground and background suggest that is not a preparatory drawing for Te atua. It could reflect an idea for an illustration for the commercial edition of Noa Noa that Gauguin subsequently rejected. In 1894 he produced eleven pen, brush, and ink drawings for the publication, each intended to introduce a chapter in the text. One of these drawings (fig. 53.13 [cat. 63]) closely resembles the print and related sculpture. Hina appears here naked and, as in the sculpture, bears tattoos around her eyes and on her abdomen; Tefatu, again with a moustache and goatee, is dressed in a pareu. They are silhouetted against a dark, globe-like form representing the earth and a lighter crescent moon; at the upper left are the words Parau Hina Tefatou (Hina addressing Tefatu).

In an 1894 watercolor entitled Pape Moe, Parau Hina Tefatou (Mysterious Water, Hina Addressing Tefatu) (fig. 53.14), Hina and Tefatu’s heads and shoulders, seen against a white sphere, seem to float above a waterfall. A Tahitian (a girl, according to Gauguin) leans over a rock to take a drink of water. The left half of the sphere’s outline, behind Hina, is dark, signifying night. At the upper right is an inscription—“Qu’importe la source / Si l’eau est délicieuse” (Never mind the source / If the water is delicious).

The couple appears again on a ceramic vase (fig. 53.15) from 1893/95. Later Gauguin pasted a hand-colored fragment of Hina and Tefatu, which he had cut from an impression of an early state of Te atua, onto page 57 of his 1893–1901 bound manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti (fig. 53.16).

The central image of Ta’aroa is a two-dimensional version of a tamanu sculpture, Tii with a Pearl, which Gauguin executed in Tahiti in 1892 (fig. 53.17). The pearl that adorns the carved figure’s hair and the mother-of-pearl oyster shell in which he sits are attributes of the creator god. According to the Polynesian creation myth, Ta’aroa was confined within a shell that he broke out of in order to create the universe. This narrative evokes the cosmic-egg mythology common to a number of early civilizations worldwide. Ta’aroa’s pose derives from that of a statue of Vishnu featured in a photograph that the artist owned from a volume of the antiquities of Java by Van Kinsbergen (fig. 53.18).

The right portion of Te atua contains the figures of Hina and Ta’aroa. Like the other two sections of the print, Hina is a quotation from an 1892 tamanu sculpture (fig. 53.12). Realized summarily, the small personage beside Hina can be seen clearly only in impressions of the first state of the print (fig. 53.19). Those of subsequent states obscure the legibility of the figure, which seems to blend with the vegetation surrounding it. Nonetheless, the figure can be identified as Ta’aroa by comparing it with a very similar representation in a later painting by Gauguin, Savage Poems (fig. 53.20). Images of Ta’aroa and Hina together can be found in other contemporary works by Gauguin. In a line drawing in the artist’s 1892/93 manuscript Ancien culte mahorie (Ancient Maori Religion), we find the deities—their genitalia prominently displayed—about to engage in sex (fig. 53.21). Ta’aroa’s face is enhanced by tattoo-like Marquesan patterns that underscore the ovoid shape of his eyes; seen from behind, Hina shows us her face in profile.

Renderings of Ta’aroa in various guises can be found in Ancien culte mahorie. One watercolor (fig. 53.22) shows a sexually aroused Ta’aroa—his face mask-like and his hair long and flowing—seated with bent knees after having created the Polynesian universe. His prominent hands and feet resemble those of Marquesan tikis. The illustration on page 14 depicts only Ta’aroa’s countenance, a mask with large, ovoid eyes at the center of a decorative setting referencing symbolic aspects of the creation of the universe (fig. 53.23). The features of his face here relate closely to those of the small idol in Savage Poems.

One of Van Kinsbergen’s photographs (fig. 53.24) provides the source for the tiny figure’s stance—a one-legged squat. In the Borobudur relief, three similar figures—attendants to Shiva known as ganas—support Buddha on his throne. Ganas are typically shown squatting under the weight they carry. That Gauguin derived pleasure from depicting these creatures is evident from their presence in several later works. One is the humorous send-up of a Tahitian meal, Repas de Tahiti (A Tahitian Meal) (fig. 53.25), in which a yellow pig is served on a native dish, known as an umete, that is supported by ganas. They appear again in the masthead for his four-page broadsheet Le sourire (The Smile), dating from 1899/1900 (see fig. 53.26).

The ceramic vase featuring Tefatu mentioned above also includes an image of Hina (fig. 53.27). She is represented as well in three drawings (fig. 53.28, fig. 53.29, and fig. 53.30 [Rewald 87]) intended for the commercial edition of Noa Noa, which in turn relates closely to a watercolor-transfer monotype (fig. 53.31). Gauguin depicted Hina with her arms alongside her body for the last time in a series of small wood-block prints he executed before leaving France for Tahiti in March 1895 (see fig. 53.32 [cat. 82.3]). At a later date, he pasted a hand-colored fragment showing Hina, cut from an impression of the earliest-known state of Te atua, onto page 59 of Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti (fig. 53.33).  
Peter Zegers

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry2" id="curatorial_entry2">The title of this print means “The God,” but it has also been translated as “The Gods,” understandably, given the plurality of figures represented. It is inscribed at the top of the image in the middle, possibly indicating that it refers especially to the central figure, and the letters are lowercase with the exception of the initial of the word atua, a choice that—without implying a monotheistic conception—is consistent with the idea of a supreme being. In any case, the title positions the plate in the mythological realm and promises a representation of the divine according to Polynesian conceptions.

No other inscription on this plate gives a name to the figures, however, so that the identification must rest on their appearance and attributes, and even more on Gauguin’s Noa Noa text and the works he had realized during his 1891–93 stay in Tahiti. For the viewer uninformed about such parallels and antecedents, the image’s protagonists—from left to right—present as a couple engaged in an intimate interaction, a seated Buddha-like figure in meditation, and a female cult figure. This impression, while it may be complemented and challenged by additional knowledge, retains its relevance insofar as Gauguin intended his works to possess a high degree of autonomy and trusted means of expression such as line, color, light, and shade to communicate directly to the mind through the senses.

Commentators on the print have generally agreed on identifying the dramatis personae as, respectively, Hina and Tefatu, Ta‘aroa, and again Hina. Peter Zegers recapitulates the corresponding arguments, including comparisons with Gauguin’s earlier works, and adds a fifth character, a tiny and barely visible Ta‘aroa in a squatting position at the extreme right (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works). The only point of contention has been the central figure, which Stephen Eisenman described as Buddha. Zegers bases his identification on the sculpture Tii with a Pearl (fig. 53.34 [Gray 94]). This identification can be further supported by Tii with a Shell (fig. 53.35 [Gray 99]), to the extent that the latter displays a more “primitive” aspect and insofar as the mother-of-pearl aureole can be seen as an attribute of Ta‘aroa. Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout’s 1837 Voyages aux îles du grand océan, Gauguin’s main source regarding ancient Polynesian culture, quotes an oral account of the creation of the world and of the gods, which the artist copied at the beginning of his 1893 manuscript Ancien culte mahorie (Ancient Maori Religion). According to this narrative, Ta‘aroa “turns himself into the universe,” and the universe becomes “the shell of Ta‘aroa.” The slightly horseshoe-shaped aureole around the central figure in Te atua is reminiscent of a shell. This suffices to connect it with Ta‘aroa, but not in an exclusive way. The formal models for this figure can be found in two Asian statues of which Gauguin possessed photographs, one of Buddha resisting the assault of Mara on a frieze of the temple of Borobudur (fig. 53.36) and the other of Vishnu in Wonosobo, Java (fig. 53.37). It therefore seems logical to assume that Gauguin conflated in his figure Ta‘aroa, Buddha, and possibly Vishnu as well. Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk similarly concluded from her analysis of Tii with a Shell and Tii with a Pearl that they incorporate “the idea that theosophically Ta‘aroa and Buddha are one and the same.”

On the left, the close encounter between Hina and Tefatu refers to a dialogue transcribed by Moerenhout under the title “Eternity of Matter,” which Gauguin had copied and illustrated in Ancien culte mahorie (fig. 53.38). According to this legend, Hina, as the “genius” or goddess of the moon, asks the “genius” or god of the earth Tefatu to grant humans a new life after death, but he refuses and decides that they must die and perish like plants and the earth itself, whereas Hina lets the moon and what it contains live again. While in the Ancien culte mahorie watercolor, the two figures are shown as equal and complementary partners, Tefatu appears dominant in Te atua and Hina’s gesture suggests she is pleading. Teilhet-Fisk remarked that, in comparison with his source, Gauguin increased the importance of Tefatu, and she supposed that the artist was thereby “perhaps consciously imposing the Christian concept of the Trinity on the Tahitian pantheon.” The importance of this scene for Gauguin is emphasized in Te atua by the placement of his monogram PGO just beneath it, in the lower-left corner of the print.

Gauguin visualized the tense dialogue related by Moerenhout in a form that can suggest an amorous encounter, a reading also made possible in other versions, such as the painting Hina Tefatou (fig. 53.39 [W 499]). It is possible that he connected the Polynesian legend with the biblical account of the Original Sin and of the ensuing Fall, which also condemned humankind to mortality. In the Getty draft manuscript of Noa Noa, Gauguin planned to introduce the Tefatu legend after a description of the painting Pape moe (fig. 53.40 [W 498]) and in a watercolor version of the same theme (fig. 53.41), a vignette with the heads of Hina and Tefatu appears above the spring of water from which the figure is about to drink, accompanied by a motto suggesting a temptation scene: “Qu’importe la source / Si l’eau est délicieuse” (“Never mind the source, as long as the water is delicious”).

At the right side of the print, the standing Hina has the hieratic appearance of a cult image. Her oversized head and almond-shaped eyes correspond to Polynesian anthropomorphic sculptures, while the greater anatomical realism and her elaborate headdress call to mind Asian prototypes, such as statues of Shiva’s consort Pārvatī. The diminutive Ta‘aroa accompanying Hina suggests that she appears here as his wife: Moerenhout attributed to them numerous children named “tiis” (ti’ii in Tahitian, tiki in Marquesan), described as “spirits inferior to the gods.” The standing Hina is one of the two types—the other being seated (see cat. 55, Commentary)—that Gauguin used when visualizing a large “idol” worshipped in pre-Christian times, for instance in Mahana no te atua (Day of the God) (fig. 53.42 [cat. 72] [W 513]), which he painted in France while working on Noa Noa. In effect, the attendants of these imaginative re-creations of the past are generally female, like the goddess herself, clearly contradicting Moerenhout’s text, which mentions that women were regarded as impure and prohibited from entering all marae (places of worship), including the small domestic ones possessed by most families. It is therefore poetic license, consistent with Gauguin’s valorization of Hina, to whom he seems to have given greater importance than did all recorded missionaries and ethnologists. This may be related to the egalitarian bent of his opinion about the sexes, which he partly inherited from his maternal grandmother, the utopian feminist Flora Tristan. Or it may be connected to the notion, expressed with a misogynist undertone by Charles Morice in his introduction to the 1901 edition of Noa Noa, that women were especially fond of Hina and that their devotion resulted, like the legend of the goddess’s plea for humankind, from the missionaries’ enervating influence.

Gauguin had also read in Moerenhout’s account that ancient Polynesians did not make anthropomorphic images of their higher deities, such as Ta‘aroa, whose “true emblems” were the toʻo (see fig. 53.43), long pieces of hollowed-out wood covered in an envelope woven of coconut-palm fiber and sometimes containing red feathers, hair, or teeth. He knew that the images placed in the marae were those of the inferior ti’is and, accordingly, referred to the sculptures included in his 1893 exhibition at Durand-Ruel, in Paris, as “Les Tiis” in the catalogue. Why did he choose then to represent in Te atua—as in some of his paintings and sculptures—the higher gods mentioned by Moerenhout in a more or less abstracted human form inspired by Indian and Southeast Asian prototypes? One reason may be that, although he was remarkably open to non-Western traditions himself, as his close study of and borrowing from Marquesan art testify, he was also aware that the common response to such forms would be of the kind demonstrated by Moerenhout, who introduced the toʻo by saying that, “as art, nothing more ridiculous and crude could be imagined.” Another reason may be the comparative, syncretic, and universalist viewpoint underlying his approach of Polynesian religion and mythology. Teilhet-Fisk compared Gauguin’s conflation of Ta‘aroa and Buddha in Tii with a Shell and Tii with a Pearl with the theosophical writings of Madame (Helena) Blavatsky, which he must have known of through his friends Émile Schuffenecker and Paul Sérusier. Another source or model could have been Édouard Schuré’s Grands initiés of 1889, which was very popular among Parisian Symbolist circles and whose program is summarized by its subtitle: Esquisse de l’histoire secrète des religions. Rama, Krishna, Hermès, Orphée, Pythagore, Platon, Jésus.

Te atua has the sculptural and architectural appearance of a frieze carved in relief, or of statues positioned in niches side by side, like the two giant representations of Buddha that once stood in indentations in the cliffs of the Bamiyan Valley in Afghanistan (fig. 53.44). From this point of view, it is the print most closely resembling the Borobudur reliefs (see fig. 53.36) that partly inspired the Noa Noa Suite, and it is most strongly reminiscent of the rubbings and paper squeeze-molds taken from monuments around the world (see “Veiled in a Cloud of Fragrance”). Should it be regarded as a Tahitian pantheon according to Gauguin after Moerenhout and a “sort of Trinity of Polynesian supernatural powers”? This hypothesis seems logical and is supported by the recapitulative quality of the print, in relation to the sculptures that informed it. But it is partly contradicted by the repetition of figures (Ta‘aroa and Hina appearing twice) and by the narrative character of the scene on the left. Although the existence of an iconographic program is improbable, one can attempt to understand how Gauguin articulated the various elements.

The directions of the arcs passing above the lateral groups, in which Zegers sees peacock flowers or meteor showers (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works), converge toward the seated figure and further emphasize its centrality. The gesture of this figure is the Bhūmisparsámudrā, by which Buddha calls the earth goddess to witness that he has resisted the tempter Māra and achieved enlightenment. If the dialogue between Hina and Tefatu is connected to the biblical Fall, by which humankind was condemned to mortality, then a parallel can also be drawn between the Buddha’s illumination and the figure of Christ as redeemer. The small tree positioned between the two groups, which also derives from reliefs at Borobudur (see fig. 53.8), could stand both for the Christian tree of the knowledge of good and evil and for the Bodhi Tree, the Ficus religiosa under which Siddhartha Gautama became Buddha; its shape is triangular and in the two impressions printed by Louis Roy under Gauguin’s guidance (see cat. 53.6), this tree is lighter than the rest of the plate, like the two aureoles.

The long hair and small breasts of the central figure qualify it as androgynous, a state that Gauguin—in accordance with many fin-de-siècle authors—regarded as superior. The respective genders of Hina and Tefatu, on the contrary, are clearly indicated. One could imagine that the enlightenment or salvation reached by the Ta‘aroa/Vishnu/Buddha/Christ figure implies a renunciation of the sexual difference, but this is not plausible in the context of Gauguin’s thought and of Polynesian cosmogony. With one hand on the small Ta‘aroa and one hand on another plant, round in shape and containing in its middle a form that resembles an open grenade, the standing Hina clearly denotes fecundity. Two broad serpentine lines surrounding her and the shrub come together to the left of the seated figure, after supporting his legs and being touched by his downward hand. Proceeding along, the line bends as if to avoid a mongoose-like animal below it and stops just before the trunk of the triangular tree, assuming a curious shape (fig. 53.45) that has not been identified. It calls to mind Marquesan motifs that fascinated Gauguin, and it can be compared with one of the most commonly used, the ipu (container), found on tattoos, war clubs, other wood carvings (see fig. 53.46), and on the tortoiseshell plaques of headdresses. Whatever its source, the most striking aspect of this motif is its reversible character, which makes the perception oscillate between a light shape on a dark ground and the opposite. In a similar way, in 1892 Gauguin had selected a Marquesan ear ornament (taiana), including a reversible figure/ground element as a model for the freely invented fence surrounding a sacred precinct in his 1892 painting Parahi te marae (The Sacred Mountain) (fig. 53.47 [W 483]; see cat. 41), and a study of this motif included a figure of Buddha (fig. 53.48).

In Parahi te marae, the reversible motif can be associated with the relationship between the lingam and the yoni, the abstract image of Shiva as the male organ of generation and its vaginal counterpart. In Te atua, the motif of the lingam is indirectly present with the standing Hina, whose outline corresponds to the shape of the eponymous sculpture (see fig. 53.49), included in the 1893 exhibition at Durand-Ruel and that magnifies the phallic shape common to all cylindrical sculptures by Gauguin. The same connection may therefore be relevant in Te atua, and the curved line moving from Hina to the seated figure could represent the process of generation allowing the sub-lunar world to surmount mortality, as well as a conjunctio oppositorum corresponding to the moment of “enlightenment.” This would agree with Moerenhout’s understanding of the Polynesian religion as “adoration of the forces of nature,” duly copied by Gauguin: according to which Ta‘aroa and Hina were the names given to the two principles—respectively male and female, active and passive, spiritual and material, invisible and visible—composing the universe and united in God.

If this interpretation is correct, Gauguin was not content with “translating” Moerenhout’s Polynesian cosmogony into an anthropomorphic pantheon compatible with Christian, Hindu, and Buddhist iconographic traditions, but rather wished to include as well aniconic elements partly inspired by Marquesan art. The same could be said of color. The theme of divinity and “enlightenment” gives a special meaning to the importance of chiaroscuro in this print, and the various impressions pulled by Gauguin can be seen as exercises in expressing the numinous, with a paradoxical climax reached in the one almost devoid of ink and purely embossed (cat. 53.2). Similarly, the choice of yellow and red, the latter especially for Louis Roy’s edition (see cat. 53.6), is consistent with the sacredness of these colors reported by Moerenhout. Although the print, with its haptic qualities and its derivation from sculptures, makes no secret of showing us not the gods but rather images of images of the gods, it is efficient at endowing these images with presence, and the title Te atua may after all evoke the divine rather than any specific deity.  
Dario Gamboni

Louis Roy printed this impression in spring–summer 1894 in an edition of about twenty-five impressions.

In the catalogue are two entries listing tikis, carved images of a Polynesian god or ancestor. The three buyers were Michel Manzi, who purchased Ia orana Maria (Hail Mary) (1891; Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York [W 428]); Edgar Degas, who bought Hina tefatou (Moon and Earth) (1893; Museum of Modern Art, New York [W 499]); and Wilhelm Hansen, who acquired Vahine no tiare (Flower Woman) (1891; Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, Copenhagen [W 420]). Galeries Durand-Ruel, Exposition d’oeuvres récentes de Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Galeries Durand-Ruel, 1893), nos. 1, 5, and 31, respectively.

Figure 51.3 was first published in Douglas W. Druick and Peter Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Auckland Art Gallery/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 25. Jean de Rotonchamp provided a contemporary description of Gauguin’s studio:

Au fond, était un hangar vitré, comportant un rez-de-chausée et deux étages. En haut de l’escalier, à la hauteur de second, un balcon desservait trois ateliers. Le troisième et dernier de ceux-ci, au bout de balcon, était celui de Gauguin. . . . Au bout de l’antichambre se trouvait l’atelier. . . . Cette assez vaste pièce, entièrement peinte en jaune de chrome clair—chrome no. 1—donnait la sensation immédiate de l’étrange et de l’imprévue. Sur les murs, balafrés de toiles barbares (At the back was a kind of windowed shed with a ground floor and two upper stories. At the top of the stairs at the second level, a balcony led to three studios. The third and last of these, at the balcony’s far end, was Gauguin’s. . . . An entrance space led to the studio. . . . This rather vast room, painted entirely in bright chrome yellow—chrome no. 1—created an immediate impression of strangeness and unpredictability. On the walls, smeared with barbaric canvases).

Jean de Rotonchamp [Louis Brouillon], Paul Gauguin 1848–1903 (É. Druet, 1906), pp. 123–24. Colta Ives identified the man at the lower-left corner of the photograph as Gauguin, wearing the Stetson hat he purchased after viewing Buffalo Bill Cody’s Wild West Show at the 1889 Exposition Universelle, Paris. Colta Ives and Susan Alyson Stein, The Lure of the Exotic: Gauguin in New York Collections, exh. cat. (Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2002), p. 12, fig. 18. The facial structure and costume of the man in the photograph are closely related to those of Gauguin’s Self-Portrait with Hat (1893/94; Musée d’Orsay, Paris [W 506].

These are Oviri (cat. 84) and Femme cueillant des fruits et Oviri (Woman Picking Fruit and Oviri) (1896/97 Kornfeld 36).

The order presented here—first proposed in Douglas Druick and Peter Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Art Institute of Chicago/Auckland City Art Gallery, 1995), pp. 23–24—reflects the unfolding of a narrative based on the themes of the ten wood-block prints. Bronwen Nicholson offered another point of view: “Dans leur ensemble, les gravures sur bois nous montrent le cycle de la vie à la tahitienne, décrivant les aspects de Tahiti qui ont saisi l’imagination de Gauguin: la naissance et la mort, l’amour et la procréation, le bain, la quête de la nourriture, les légendes tahitiennes” (Taken together, the woodcuts show us the Tahitian life cycle, describing the aspects of Tahiti that had captured Gauguin’s imagination: birth and death, love and procreation, bathing, the quest for nourishment, Tahitian legends). Bronwen Nicholson, Noa Noa, transcription, ed. Pierre Petit (J. J. Pauvert, 1988), pp. 113, 123–38.

For another point of view, which marries the prints to the way the text is ordered, see Alastair Wright and Calvin Brown, Gauguin’s Paradise Remembered, exh. cat. (Princeton University Art Museum/Yale University Press, 2010). For Starr Figura, the prints do not follow a narrative; she divided them into three thematic categories: “portrayals of daily life, night-time scenes of figures communing with or haunted by spirits, and images depicting Tahitian gods and myths.” Starr Figura, “Noa Noa and the Tahitian Idyll,” in Figura, Gauguin: Metamorphoses, with essays by Elizabeth Childs, Hal Foster, and Erika Mosier, exh. cat. (Museum of Modern Art, New York, 2013), p. 92.

Alocasia macrorrhizos. The ape plant is known in English as elephant’s ear. With its giant leaves, which point up, the plant can reach heights of ten to twelve feet. It is not to be confused with the taro plant (genus: Colocasia; species: C. esculenta), whose leaves point down.

The serpentine line extending in front of Ta’aroa has been identified as a pandanus leaf. See Mary Lynn Zink, “Paul Gauguin’s Ta’aroa, the Tahitian God of Creation” (Ph.D. diss., University of California at Santa Barbara, 1976), p. 61.

Tamanu (Alexandrian laurel); Calophyllum inophyllum. Another Tahitian name for this wood is ati.

All but two relate directly to the sculpture and its two-dimensional counterpart, Te atua. The two exceptions are found in Gauguin’s reflections on the Polynesian creation myth, which he recorded in Ancien culte mahorie (Ancient Maori Religion) based on information that he had culled selectively from an 1837 travel account: Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertand, 1837), vol. 1, chap. 2, pp. 416–569. The first, on page 7, depicts the couple: Tefatu, who sports a moustache and goatee, and Hina. The second, on page 13, shows Hina and Tefatu seated on the ground and conversing.

Both illustrations include imagery closely related to Marquesan carvings. In the first, for example, Tefatu resembles an ancient tiki (a large figure carved out of wood or volcanic rock). In the second, the stylization of the figures’ hands and feet are informed by Marquesan precedents. Gauguin reprised this subject again in a watercolor illustration on page 55 of Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti.

Galeries Durand-Ruel, Exposition d’oeuvres récentes de Paul Gauguin (Galeries Durand-Ruel, 1893). Next to the title one sees Easter Island glyphs, a star, and a crescent moon.

This sheet was first reproduced and discussed by Marcel Guérin in his L’oeuvre gravé de Gauguin (H. Floury, 1927; Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1980), pp. xv and xvii.

See cats. 61–63, Commentary, on the two versions of Noa Noa: the suite of wood-block prints and the commercial edition.

See Paul Gauguin, Noa Noa (Éd. de l’Association des Amis du Musée Gauguin à Tahiti/Gauguin and Oceania Foundation, 1987), p. 16.

Van Kinsbergen’s albumen print also inspired a later wood-block print by Gauguin, Buddha (1898/99 [Kornfeld 45]).

See Mary Lynn Zink, “Gauguin’s Poèmes Barbares and the Tahitian Chant of Creation,” Art Journal 38, no. 1 (Fall 1978), pp. 18–21.

At the bottom right of the sheet is the image of a flower, tentatively identified as a waterhyssop (Bacopa monnieri).

Remnant of original wood-block matrix; Národní Galerie, Prague. See Libuŝe Sýkorová, Gauguin Woodcuts (P. Hamlyn, 1963), no. 8.

This sheet belonged to a portfolio of miscellaneous drawings, Documents Tahiti: 1891–1892, that has been dispersed. See Galerie Marcel Guiot, Exposition Paul Gauguin, Aquarelles, Monotypes, Dessins (Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942), no. 55, p. 32.

The translation The God was given by Bengt Danielsson in “Gauguin’s Tahitian Titles,” Burlington Magazine 109 (Apr. 1967), p. 232, no. 59. The translation The Gods was given by (among others) Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, with assistance from Christine E. Stauffer, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance from Christine E. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), pp. 76-81, cat. 17; Steven F. Eisenman, “Te Atua or The Gods," in Paul Gauguin: Artist of Myth and Dream, ed. Stephen F. Eisenman, exh. cat. (Skira, 2007), p. 304, cat. 83; and Calvin Brown, “Paradise Remembered: The Noa Noa Woodcuts,” in Alastair Wright and Brown, Gauguin’s Paradise Remembered: The Noa Noa Prints, exh. cat. (Princeton University Art Museum/Yale University Press, 2010), pp. 117–18, cat. 20. “The Gods” would normally be te mau atua. Ziva Amishai-Maisels wrote, “The meaning is ‘The god’ in the singular, although Gauguin apparently uses it here in the plural”; Amishai-Maisels, “Gauguin’s Early Tahitian Idols,” Art Bulletin 40, no. 2 (June 1978), p. 339, n. 44.

The dictionary of the Académie Tahitienne indicates that atua can be used for polytheistic and monotheistic gods; accessed Nov. 29, 2015. The inscription in the present print reads te Alua, which seems to have resulted from a technical error.

See Gauguin to Émile Schuffenecker, Jan. 14, 1885, in Correspondance de Paul Gauguin: Documents; Témoignages, ed. Victor Merlhès, vol. 1, 1873–1888 (Fondation Singer-Polignac, 1984), pp. 87–89, no. 65.

This figure is mentioned and described as a “gnome” in Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance from Christine E. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 76.

Steven F. Eisenman, “Te Atua or The Gods,” in Paul Gauguin: Artist of Myth and Dream, ed. Stephen F. Eisenman, exh. cat. (Skira, 2007), p. 304. In 1995 Douglas Druick and Peter Zegers noted that the figure is “formally inspired by Far Eastern sculptures of Buddha” and surmised that Gauguin “may have intended this figure to represent Ta’aroa, the androgynous creator god of the Polynesian universe, of whom Hina, in one of her manifestations, was the spouse.” Druick and Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Auckland City Art Gallery/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 51, cat. 17.

Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, pp. 419–21; and Paul Gauguin, Ancien culte mahorie, ed. René Huygue (1951; Hermann, 2001), p. 9. On the extent of Gauguin’s dependence on Moerenhout’s book, see Ziva Amishai-Maisels, “Gauguin’s Early Tahitian Idols,” Art Bulletin 40, no. 2 (June 1978), p. 331, n. 4. Amishai-Maisels, however, thought that Gauguin carved Tii with a Shell before reading Moerenhout, used a shell “for primitivizing reasons,” and reinterpreted it as “the Universe-Shell of Taaroa” after discovering Voyages aux îles du grand océan. This chronology of the events was rejected by Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk in Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), p. 49. Moerenhout had translated his Tahitian source somewhat tentatively by writing that “the universe is only the body or the shell of Taaroa,” observing that the word paa meant principally an “egg” but could sometimes refer to “the body or the exterior parts of an object”; Moerenhout, Voyages, vol. 1, p. 421. Gauguin, however, only retained “the shell.” Teilhet-Fisk quoted another source and observed that “the legend of Ta’aroa always begins with him sitting in his shell” (p. 51). The cosmogenesis and theogenesis transmitted by Moerenhout had rapidly become famous and was the basis for Charles Marie René Leconte de Lisle’s poem “La Genèse polynésienne” (“The Polynesian Genesis”), included in his 1862 collection Poèmes barbares. Gauguin knew this poem, as a reference in the Louvre manuscript of Noa Noa shows; René Huygue, “La clef de Noa Noa,” in Paul Gauguin, Ancien culte mahorie, ed. René Huygue, facsimile ed. (1951; Hermann, 2001), p. 27.

Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), p. 54. See also Charles F. Stuckey, “Idol with a Pearl” and “Idol with a Shell,” in Richard R. Brettell, Françoise Cachin, Claire Frèches-Thory, and Charles F. Stuckey, The Art of Paul Gauguin, with assistance from Peter Zegers, exh. cat. (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C./Art Institute of Chicago/New York Graphic Society Books, 1988), pp. 250–52, cat. 138, and pp. 274–76, cat. 151.

Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, pp. 428–29; Paul Gauguin, Ancien culte mahorie, ed. René Huygue, facsimile ed. (1951; Hermann, 2001), p. 13.

Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk compared Hina’s raised hand with the Buddhist abhayamūdra or “symbol of appeasement”; Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), p. 59.

Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), p. 52.

The attitudes and expressions of Hina and Tefatu in this work seem to agree with the interpretation of the legend put forth by Charles Morice in his preface to the catalogue of Gauguin’s November 1893 exhibition at Durand-Ruel, Paris (with reference to the painting) and in his contributions to the 1901 version of Noa Noa, according to which Hina’s plea was misguided and Tefatu’s refusal justified, because “life can only be fecundated in death” (“la vie ne se féconde que dans la mort”). Charles Morice, preface, in Galeries Durand-Ruel, Exposition d’œuvres récentes de Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Galeries Durand-Ruel, 1893), p. 6.

This motto is a paraphrase of Alfred de Musset’s verse “Qu’importe le flacon, pourvu qu’on ait l’ivresse” (“Never mind the bottle, as long as it gets you drunk”) in the dedication of his Un spectacle dans un fauteuil (Librairie de la Revue des deux-mondes, 1834).

Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, pp. 458­–60; Paul Gauguin, Ancien culte mahorie, ed. René Huygue, facsimile ed. (1951; Hermann, 2001), pp. 20–21.

Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, p. 469.

Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: The Paintings of the First Voyage to Tahiti (Garland, 1977), p. 284, n. 12; Nicholas Wadley, ed., Noa Noa: Gauguin’s Tahiti, trans. Jonathan Griffin (Phaidon, 1985), p. 74, n. 42. A different opinion, however, was advanced by Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), pp. 77–78.

Paul Gauguin and Charles Morice, Noa Noa (La Plume, 1901), pp. 14–15.

See Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, pp. 471–74; Philippe Peltier, “Gauguin, Artist and Ethnographer,” in George T. M. Shackelford and Claire Frèches-Thory, Gauguin Tahiti, with additional essays by Isabelle Cahn et al., exh. cat. (MFA Publications, 2004), pp. 47–65; Stephen Hooper, “Embodying Divinity: The Life of A’a,” Journal of the Polynesian Society 116 (2007), p. 140; and Suzanne Greub, ed., Gauguin Polynesia, exh. cat. (Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, Copenhagen/Seattle Art Museum/Hirmer, 2011), p. 115.

Galeries Durand-Ruel, Exposition d’oeuvres récentes de Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Galeries Durand-Ruel, Paris, 1893), p. 20, cat. 46.

In this connection, Laurence Madeline pointed to the presence of the great statue of Buddha from the Japanese temple of Nara that was on display at the 1889 Exposition Universelle, Paris; Madeline, Ultra-sauvage: Gauguin sculpteur (A. Biro, 2002), pp. 115–16.

Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, p. 471. Loti did not see Polynesian art differently; he wrote in 1879, “Idols of their god are still constantly found in the hands of these islanders, a hideous embryonic shape. The queen has four such images carved on the sticks of her fan” (“On trouve encore entre les mains des indigènes plusieurs images de leur Dieu. C’est un personnage à figure hideuse, semblable à un embryon humain. La reine a quatre de ces horreurs, sculptées sur le manche de son éventail”). Pierre Loti [Julien Viaud], Le mariage de Loti [Rarahu. Idylle polynésienne, 1879], ed. Bruno Vercier (Flammarion, 1991), p. 108; Loti, Tahiti: The Marriage of Loti, trans. Clara Bell (1925; Kegan Paul, 2002), p. 78.

Ziva Amishai-Maisels showed that Moerenhout and Gauguin shared this syncreticism; Amishai-Maisels, “Gauguin’s Early Tahitian Idols,” Art Bulletin 40, no. 2 (June 1978), pp. 331, 339. She thought that Gauguin’s belief in idol worship by the ancient Tahitians was based on Moerenhout’s passage on the initiation of an Areoi chief and that the artist “was predisposed to this belief, for the Judeo-Christian heritage tends to identify all pagan religion with idol worship as it was practiced in the Mediterranean area” (p. 332, n. 10).

See Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), p. 54.

Édouard Schuré, Les grands initiés. Esquisse de l’histoire secrète des religions: Rama, Krishna, Hermès, Orphée, Pythagore, Platon, Jésus (Perrin, 1889). See also Philippe Verdier, “Un manuscrit de Gauguin: L’esprit moderne et le catholicisme,” Wallraf-Richartz Jahrbuch 46–47 (1985–86), pp. 273–98.

Charles F. Stuckey, “Hina and Fatu,” in Richard R. Brettell, Françoise Cachin, Claire Frèches-Thory, and Charles F. Stuckey, The Art of Paul Gauguin, with assistance from Peter Zegers, exh. cat. (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C./Art Institute of Chicago/New York Graphic Society Books, 1988), p. 255, cat. 140.

See Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), p. 50, with reference to Christopher Gray, Sculpture and Ceramics of Paul Gauguin (Johns Hopkins Press, 1963; repr., Hacker Art Books, 1980), pp. 56–57. The protuberance on the summit of the central figure’s head in Te atua compares with the pearl in Idol with a Pearl and also with the Buddhist urna (see Teilhet-Fisk, p. 186, n. 52).

See Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), pp. 50–53. Ziva Amishai-Maisels believed that Gauguin was especially attracted to this statue (which she identified as depicting Shiva and as coming from Dieng in Java) “because of its androgynous form”; Amishai-Maisels, “Gauguin’s Early Tahitian Idols,” Art Bulletin 40, no. 2 (June 1978), p. 339.

A similar plant stands between Eve and the serpent in Gauguin’s 1890 painting Exotic Eve (Pola Museum of Art, Hakone, Japan [W 389]).

Mary Lynn Zink identified it as a pandanus leaf, but this is not convincing; Zink, “Paul Gauguin’s Ta’aroa, the Tahitian God of Creation” (Ph.D. diss., University of California at Santa Barbara, 1976), p. 61.

See Karl von den Steinen, Les marquisiens et leur art, trans. from German by Helma Arcosanzo (German ed. 1925–28; Musée de Tahiti et des Îles, 2005), vol. 1, pp. 163–64. According to Steinen, the ipu motif derives from the upper part (hands and arms) of the etua (human body) motif. Gauguin was familiar with Marquesan motifs from tattoos in particular. See Lieutenant Jénot, “Le premier séjour de Gauguin à Tahiti d’après le manuscript Jénot (1891–1893),” Gazette des beaux-arts, 6th ser. (Jan.–Apr. 1956 [1958]), pp. 120–21, for photographs of tattooed Marquesans that Gauguin showed to Jénot in Papeete. Motifs on Hina and Tefatu on the left may be tattoos rather than pareu patterns; see Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983).

See Dario Gamboni, Paul Gauguin: The Mysterious Centre of Thought, trans. Chris Miller (Reaktion, 2014), pp. 335–47.

On the Western reception of linga symbolism, see Partha Mitter, Much Maligned Monsters: A History of European Reactions to Indian Art (University of Chicago Press, 1977), pp. 73–104.

A curvilinear vegetal motif can be seen in a similar position on both sides of the main figure of Tii with a Shell and was interpreted by Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk as symbolizing “the creation of Tefatou” resulting from the union of Ta’aroa with Hina; Teilet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), p. 53 and fig. 17.

Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, p. 563; Paul Gauguin, Ancien culte mahorie, ed. René Huygue, facsimile ed. (1951; Hermann, 2001), p. 32. This metaphysical interpretation was developed at length by Charles Morice in the 1901 edition of Noa Noa; Paul Gauguin and Morice, Noa Noa (La Plume, 1901), pp. 182–85. See also E. S. Craighill Handy, “Polynesian Religion,” Bishop Museum Bulletin 34 (1927), p. 37.

See Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), for example, vol. 1, pp. 472–73. See also Philippe Peltier, “Gauguin, Artist and Ethnographer,” in George T. M. Shackelford and Claire Frèches-Thory, Gauguin Tahiti, with additional essays by Isabelle Cahn et al., exh. cat. (MFA Publications, 2004), pp. 52, 63; and Philippe Peltier, “Gauguin: Artiste ethnographe,” in Gauguin Tahiti: L’atelier des tropiques, exh. cat. (Éds. de la Réunion des Musées Nationaux, 2003), pp. 33–36.
